summary: This is an internal email chain among U.S. Attorney's Office staff discussing a FOIA case related to Jeffrey Epstein. It summarizes a challenging oral argument before Judge Engelmayer, who expressed skepticism about the breadth of the government's withholdings under FOIA exemption 7(A) and will order an in camera review. The email also mentions the need to coordinate with Main Justice due to a recent change in administration.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presided over the oral argument in the Epstein FOIA case, expressed skepticism about the government's 7(A) withholdings, and will order an in camera review of the withheld documents.

persons.name: Audrey
persons.context: The Court directed the email author to communicate with Audrey, asking her to consider the case and evaluate whether to confer with Main Justice on the FOIA response, particularly in light of the recent change in administration.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Author of the forwarded email, who participated in the oral argument, is ordering the transcript, and will coordinate follow-up communications and a call with colleagues.

connections.description: The AUSA appeared before Judge Engelmayer in court for an oral argument regarding the Epstein FOIA case.
The AUSA was directed by the court to communicate with Audrey regarding case evaluation and potential consultation with Main Justice.

events.title: Oral Argument in Epstein FOIA Case
events.description: A challenging, approximately 2-hour oral argument was held before Judge Engelmayer regarding FOIA requests related to Jeffrey Epstein. The court expressed skepticism about the breadth of the government's 7(A) withholdings.

events.title: Expected Court Order for In Camera Review
events.description: Judge Engelmayer is expected to enter an order directing that documents withheld under FOIA exemption 7(A) be produced to the court for in camera review, and to specify marking for materials related to the Tartaglione case.

keyFacts: Judge Engelmayer is skeptical of the government's broad use of FOIA exemption 7(A) to withhold documents in the Epstein case and will order an in camera review.
The court is concerned about distinguishing between materials withheld due to potential interference with the Noel case versus the Tartaglione case.
The court directed the AUSA to have Audrey consider the case and evaluate conferring with Main Justice, noting the recent change in administration could impact the FOIA response.
The oral argument was described as 'pretty rough' for the government, lasting approximately two hours.
